Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2008 09:37PM bbmom wrote: Hi Alli, My SNB came back positive so the surgeon removed all of the axillary nodes which turned ot to be 17 for me. I have the cording in my arm and down my ribcage. I was told to do the exercises recommended for recovery after mast. and as much stretching as I could stand. It can be painful, but the doctor told me the more stretching I could do against it the better. As long as I do this I'm OK, but it comes back if I go several days without doing the exercises.

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 10:37AM bbmom wrote: I have had cording on and off for the last 2 years. The last time I had problems the cord was not as defined as before but I did have a couple of bumps along the cord appear inside my elbow. I find that I can keep it under control as long as I do my arm exercises. If I stop for a period of time it usually flares up. I also have problems on and off down my ribcage, but I haven't found any exercise that seem to work on it. It will eventually go away as mysteriously as it appeared. A friend of mine that is over a local hospital's pt unit had one of her therapist go for a training seminar recently and she had  her ask about cording. She was told it's treated the same as LE. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 10:43PM bbmom wrote: Carol, I know how you feel. I have been having some different pains and discomfort for a while. I hate thinking everytime I have a different feeling that something could be wrong and I hate running to the doctor for every little thing. I finally talked myself into calling for an appt today. I figured I'd rather waste my docs time then maybe later be sorry that I didn't go. It's hard not to freak out when you have a new pain. I'm coming up on my 3 yr cancerversary and I find that I tend to be more worried about recurrance around this time. I can't help thinking what may have escaped through my lymph system, then I have to remind myself that was why I went through chemo. God Bless!

Posts.Title: Recurrence ? Firelady Gitane

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 03:44AM - edited Apr 22, 2010 03:45AM by bbmom I got my CT results today.  In 4 months I went from subcentimeter lesions that could not be identified as cancer to a 4 cm lesion on my liver. I was given the choice of Faslodex to replace the Femara, chemo in pill form or carboplatin and gemzar. My onc told me that the liver didn't usually respond to hormone therapy. After spending 4 months doing hormone therapy with no response at all I wouldn't take that chance. He said they normally saw a better response with the carbo and gemzar, but the pills would have lesser side effects. It was my choice which I wanted to go with. I chose to do the carbo and gemzar and am hoping that it'll take care of the lesions on my liver. I start this Friday with one, next Friday with the other and one week off. Sometime before tomorrow and next Friday I'll have a port put in. If anyone has done this regimen already I'd appreciate any informaition on what your experience was with them. Thanks and God Bless

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 03:41AM bbmom wrote: My onc doesn't believe in doing any scans either. I was told statistically the treatment and outcome for a recurrence is pretty much the same whether it's caught early or not. My first onc didn't even do bloodwork as part of my check-up. Honestly, sometimes I feel like just having my family physician follow me. I know if I'm not feeling well he won't hesitate to send me for any test he thinks needs to be done. God Bless!
Posts.Title: What's your opinion on post-treatment tests staceyshusband bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2007 04:22PM bbmom wrote: Hi Roxy, I hope you're feeling better. Hang in there. I am another stage 3c. Just passed my 2 year anniversary and am NED.  My onc would never give me a prognosis which always made me feel like he didn't have a whole lot of hope for me. I had the same drugs, just in a different order and have been on tamoxifen for a little over a year. Other than hot flashes I haven't had any other side effects and even that is better. Treatment can be tough but you can do it. Don't ever give up. You'll be done before you know it. God Bless! "The Will of God will never take you where the Grace of God will not protect you."

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 09:07PM bbmom wrote: I chose mast to avoid radiation. Turned out I had to have it anyway. I had a mast on the cancer side, did chemo and rads. By the time I finished treatment I had decided when I had recon I'd have the other breast removed. I think the biggest factor in that decision was because my mammo had never picked up the lump and by the time I felt it I was stage IIIC. I didn't trust mammo results and didn't want to take a chance of that happening with the other breast.
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 06:30AM bbmom wrote: Wavesworld, I was dx with bone mets in December. I've been on Femara and Zometa since. My alk phos went from 76 in Dec. to 136 this past week. The CT in December identified some suspicious spots on my liver. I had another CT done last week but haven't gotten my results yet. From what I've read about high alk phos levels it could be a problem with the liver or rapid bone growith. I'm hoping in my case that since the Zometa is supposed to strengthen the bone that this is the cause. I guess I won't know until I get my CT results.
